Posts.Content: I had my last of 8 chemo cycles on 23 May and felt just like you! I had a good response to the chemo meaning I could avoid mastectomy and we were talking about breast conservation. I was told I may lose my nipple because it seemed my residual cancer was attached - and needed a chuck taken so would be lopsided but was given options of reconstruction or therapeutic mammoplasty. I elected for the latter as I'm a slim 59 and the bane of my life has been my 32H boobs which have now given in to gravity! Basically therapeutic mammoplasty is a breast reduction (with a lift thrown in!) so while removing the cancer area they took more to achieve a size I wanted (hard to choose - I went for somewhere between D and E - obviously they can't guarantee!) My surgeon would not do both breasts as she said after all the chemo I had had (all high dose Abraxane and Cychlophosphamide which she said is about the toughest they can throw at us) my body would struggle with such a long op, and the risk of infection (higher because of the chemo) would double. The op on 4 July went well - some chemo side effects eg lot of bleeding during op so I had to have a drain, and lot of sickness after so had to stay in 3 days ( but then I've always been a sicky sort which was why they threw every anti sickness thing at me during chemo!) but pain was so much less than I expected and manageable with co codamol.  I had a slight blip with some surface infection covering about an inch of scar but soon sorted. I am absolutely delighted with the result - a very perky, non droopy 20 year old looking boob! She also saved my nipple and reattached. I was amazed that the joins are just sort of butted up together (like wallpaper joins if you get what I mean) and honestly look as if I had the op months ago, so very neat. Even after only 4 days when the dressings came off to remove the drain I couldn't believe how neat and good it was - lot of colourful bruising, but the shape and joins were brilliant. Also all 3 lymph nodes clear and clear margins (helped by the fact I have 370gms removed I guess!). The pathology also showed that the chemo had blasted my grade 3 (3,3,3) aggressive cancer to oblivion and the residual was grade 2 which my oncologist is absolutely thrilled with! Can't wait to get the other done, but she wants to wait 6 months post radiotherapy, so seeing her at the end of Jan with a potential April date). I can even get an underwired bra on with my comfie insert inside for when I go out - and am going for a silicon prosthetic fitting. So all in all it was an absolute breeze compared with the chemo - and great to think that I have got rid of the cancer inside me. I asked lots of questions and also took advantage of a session with my breast care nurse to prepare me for the surgery and afterwards which was offered - about an hour and a half - as well as a folder of info to take away, and my comfie insert to take with me. Ask about what surgery options are available and why they are recommending whatever way forward for you. Ask for a session with your breast care nurse. If you need to think about it, do so. Hope this helps - sorry, bit of a ramble, but wanted you to see that this next stage is the good one.

Posts.Content: Hi Paula I suffer from migraines - my worst was being locked into one for over 6 months and my nervous system starting to collapse including vertigo, speech loss etc. Mine also seemed to be cyclical and definitely hormone related. I didn't opt for the cold cap - didn't fancy the added length of time, the extreme discomfort, the odds of it working - and my oncologist really didn't like them and felt that, although not yet proven, there were possible links to secondary brain metasteses. He is an internationally renowned Professor and has been pioneering in this field and his opinion was good enough for me. (Given that my treatment has been incredible and clearly there has been no expense spared in the level of care I have received, I do not believe the cost factor was an issue here if I had pushed). So I can't help you with this part of your question - but the thought of something that might induce headaches was also a factor for me. I was also worried about triggering migraines during chemo (8 x3 weekly cycles of TC - straight to taxotere as I've a slight heart problem so FE was out). Interestingly I didn't have a single one in 6 months which is a record for me. So in my case the chemo definitely didn't trigger anything - and in a bizarre way seemed to put them on hold. I finished chemo at the end of May (surgery 4 July and waiting to start RT) - and only had one since then, and none since starting Tamoxifen. I occasionally took naratriptan during chemo if I had any migraine indicators (I get visual indicators and if I take the naratriptan this has usually stopped the migraine developing). My oncologist was happy about this medication. I lost all my hair in the second week of the first cycle - it's not nice, and once it had really come out in huge handfuls my husband shaved it off for me which made the final part easier as it wasn't so visible. Once it was shaved off it was easier - and I found lots of lovely stylish headwear (didn't like wearing my wig at all) and adapted pretty quickly. I think the thought of losing my hair was actually more horrifying than the reality as I believe it is for most of us.  Hope this helps and good luck

Posts.Content: I’m reeling at the moment and would like advice on what questions I need to ask. I was originally diagnosed with invasive ductal breast cancer in Oct 2015 - Grade 3 aggressive and fast growing 8.5cmx6.5cm. I had 8 cycles of chemo, which shrunk it and went for the option of therapeutic mammoplasty in July 2016, followed by radiotherapy. I had another op on the other breast in July 2017 to remove ADH cells and reduce to match my other breast. More cosmetic surgery in July 2018. I found a lump in the original in Dec 2019. Everything pointed to fat necrosis - nothing on mammogram or ultrasound that suggested cancer, the biopsy was inconclusive but didn’t show anything cancerous. I had an excision biopsy in Feb 2019 as due to my history to be on the safe side. Saw surgeon for the results on Monday - he said my original cancer had returned (didn’t know the grade) and I had to have a mastectomy as I couldn’t have radiotherapy to that area again. He said we could talk about reconstruction “when the dust had settled”. He has requested CT and bone scans to check for any spread. Op to be within 4 weeks after scan results in. I really didn’t see it coming as they had kept saying nothing to worry about. I realise now that I have a shed load of uncertainty (as well as all the other emotions!). The cancer is ER+ve as it was last time - I’ve been on tamoxifen for the 2.5 years between original surgery and finding the lump......just been told to stop taking it ready for surgery. I am ringing the breast care nurse this morning to ask to meet with someone - my questions so far are: exactly why do I need a mastectomy? what is actually there that needs removing now? is there another option - ie monitoring and/or other treatment?  what are the risks if I don’t have a mastectomy? What mastectomy options are available eg reconstruction at the time of mastectomy and why this hasn’t been discussed/offered; if not possible what type of reconstruction is likely to be the best option for me and in what timeframe? My question is are there other questions I need to be asking as my brain is a bit in freefall - I really hadn’t expected to be in this position again, and certainly not so soon. Any advice is greatly appreciated, thank you Judy

Posts.Content: Hi Hannah Yes - it's hard slowing down and giving things up - I love my busy life mainly as its full of things I love doing! Managed to keep doing quite a lot but have had to learn to seriously cut down and pace myself. I've had the same idiotic response with spas! It's so frustrating but I managed to get it sorted and have been for facials and massage while having chemo. At first I pointed out to them that my oncology centre actually offer complementary therapy free of charge as they see it as therapeutic and helpful so couldn't see what their problem was. I also told them that I had been hospitalised at one point during my treatment and that the oncology unit had their own complementary therapist (a volunteer) who offered aromatherapy, massage, reiki, reflexology etc. Even the fact that I regularly see an aromatherapist for massage, reiki and reflexology didn't work! Eventually they agreed that if I got a letter from my GP they would allow me to come.......felt like being at school and needing a letter from my Mum! Had another exchange then as I didn't think my GP would be in a position to comment as he is not an oncologist and has no idea of my regime (and I begrudged that I would have to pay!). Finally they agreed to accept a letter from my BC nurse who I explained was a specialist in both oncology and my care and part of the team looking after me. The letter reads -  "There are no medical reasons why Judy cannot attend a spa day on....and enjoy any treatments you have on offer. We promote complementary therapies within our department for people on and off treatment and see their value in terms of aiding relaxation and improvising individual's wellbeing." Love the tone that has a slightly "up yours" feel to it! This has done the trick and I'm pleased to report that I have attended a couple of spa days without anything dropping off, having seizures on the massage table, passing some deadly cancer virus to the therapists through my skin or frightening the other guests (other than a few double takes at my bald head, but that's totally understandable!). I hope any of the above arguments might do the trick or you can get a letter from your BC nurse. Perseverance seemed to do the trick......I think I even mentioned the words discriminating against cancer victims at one point which seemed to freak them! Very evilly I started to actually enjoy the email exchange I was having with them! Good luck - and hope you get to enjoy that spa day soon. Judy xx

I think mine were always at their worst due to the GCSF injections. Some peripheral neuropathy - toes are worst but gabapentin is really helping. Posts.Content: Good evening everyone I have seen two Macmillan TV adverts this evening, as well as lots of adverts on their Facebook site - and this website - for Brave the Shave, This is encouraging people to raise money for people affected by cancer by shaving their head - it has fostered a climate where people think it is showing support to people who have lost their hair by doing this too. Even my own daughters offered to shave their heads when they knew I was to have chemo and lose my hair - talk about brainwashing! I can't think of anything that would have made me more upset than to see them lose their hair too. I have pretty much powered my way through 8 cycles of DC and had every side effect it could throw at me, one stay of a week in hospital, and four times they called me in because of various things, two bad reactions in the chair - but the one thing that reduced me to tears wasn't being told I had cancer, it was being told I would lose all my hair in the second week of the first cycle. And I don't need to tell any of you how hateful I found having huge handfuls come out in the shower (and I had short hair so hadn't thought it would be so horrid). And then your eyebrows and eyelashes go - and your femininity feels like it's being stripped away bit by bit. Frankly I find people who say they will get their head shaved as support, and that say they do it to "share" our experience haven't a clue! They might choose this, we haven't chosen it - and wouldn't. It may sound over the top to some of you, but I find this whole campaign offensive, insensitive and patronising - particularly seeing people smile while having their head shaved, and people cheering. I didn't smile, and my daughter and husband didn't feel like cheering when they shaved my head. Ok I'm cool with my look now - the very shiny head (not a short razor clipped look) - but I would prefer not to have had to experience any of this. If you agree - please let me know. I have messaged Macmillan previously and never even had a response. I've commented on Facebook under their posts in the past urging people to find fun ways to raise money (and there are so many) and not to do this for me.........and there is always a huge response in terms of "likes" and comments from people in our reluctant community. If people are with me - maybe we can convince Macmillan to stop this barbaric approach to fund raising. In fact he is incredibly focussed and it can come across as condescending but actually I've found I like his style as I got used to it!  I recall at the first meeting he told me I was down for 6 or 8 - he said that this meant if I was a whinger it would be 6, if I had grit he would get 8 out of me! Fortunately I have a dry sense of humour and love a challenge! He really focusses on how I got on in each pre chemo review as he wants to make the next one better - despite his rough style I have realised he cares deeply and have grown to love him to bits. I found keeping a detailed diary each day of how I felt and then consolidating it in prep for the review really helpful - and he loves it! While I was getting changed last time he actually told my husband that I am impressive - felt like I'd been awarded Olympic gold!! Sounds like he has given you sound advice though - all good stuff. On the wig front - I was sorted with mine as routine pre chemo. Standard fee of £60 for whatever I chose as rest subsidised. In hindsight I wish I had waited until afterwards as I think the fit and how it looks changes when hair is gone - and actually I have never worn it as it feels heavy and uncomfortable, and very different to how it felt when I tried it with hair. Much prefer my ever growing range of headwear! Check in to the chemo club - there is a great list of things to help. One weird thing was that C made the inside of my nose very sore - combatted by shoving Vaseline up from day 1 and brilliant - so my tip of the day! Good luck - and tell them about everything as they have all sorts of things to make it better! Not sure if you were told the first tends to be worst - a) because basically your body says what the f#*k as it hasn't experienced it before and b) you identify which side effects are yours and your oncologist can learn from this and prescribe you meds - hence the diary as it's easy to forget by week 3. Sorry - rambled for ever but again best of luck xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Bev I've just had my 6th of 8 chemos pre surgery. Couldn't have FEC so started straight in on Docetaxel and Cychlophosphamide - changed Docetaxel for nab paclitaxel on the third. Also have steroids with the nab p fir my joints. I put about 12lbs on with the first three cycles and decided enough was enough as I am a gold WW member and had maintained my weight for years - seems an added insult to put weight on on top of everything else we have, at least we could lose it! I started WW on 19 Feb and have lost half a stone to date - slow but steady - my actual goal was just not to put more on so this is great!  It works well as basically I make sure I have all the foods I fancy for the bad times (usually first week) but they are from the ones that won't make me gain and there are loads. Fruit is perfect fit me - and when I can't manage anything else I love Warburtons thins with lightest Philadelphia which have replaced digestive biscuits!  It was good to take back control! My leader is brilliant and also had the added and unexpected bonus of a group of people really rooting for me on both levels and really feel supported in the group. Don't hesitate - go for it - it has boosted my mood no end! Good luck Judy xx

Posts.Content: In October I was diagnosed with grade 3 aggressive and fast growing breast cancer - my lump is 6.5cm.  After three lots of biopsies and a lot of discussion it was recommended that the best way forward for me is 8 cycles of chemo followed by surgery (hopefully WLE if it shrinks etc) then more chemo and or radiotherapy. Originally I was to have 4xFEC followed by 4xDC but now all DC as I have a mild/moderate leaking heart valve. I have taken things pretty much in my stride with the rare teary moment (particularly when I lost my hair after two weeks of the first cycle!) and generally feel surprisingly positive - I worry sometimes I'm not worrying!  I had a 4 day stay in hospital just after the first cycle at Christmas, but stabilised ready for cycle 2 - and a bad reaction during chemo 2 but we got there eventually!  So I'm just coming out of the other side of week 1 of my second chemo  (it's not fun, tough going with the side effects but I know I can do it - and have an amazing husband and daughters cheering from the side lines). My 81 year old mother had BC about 30 years ago (small lumpectomy and radiotherapy) and has just found she has an inverted nipple. She has been referred to the screening clinic on Monday.  I honestly don't feel up to being with her for the "allow up to two hours" appointment - I'm dreadfully tired, and this will be the start of my vulnerable week 2 and the hospital she has been referred to have a poor record with infections.  My Dad and husband are going with her - but she clearly feels very unsupported by me. Frankly she has been pretty difficult since my diagnosis - making it all about her and how difficult it is at her time of life to have a daughter diagnosed with cancer (so selfish of me!). I'm obviously hoping she is clear - no one wants to go through this crap, not least in their 80's - I'm 58 and finding it tough going.  I'm selfishly dreading if she isn't for me too - and haven't felt I can voice it anywhere as I feel so guilty for feeling this way - and sorry for dumping it here. Obviously I would want to support her but I'm having to pull on all my resources for myself at the moment and don't know how much I will have left. And on chemo weeks I'm pretty rubbish and not capable of anything much at all as being hit hard with side effects. I'm not looking for answers as I don't think there are any really - I'm just feeling so helpless and guilty, maybe because I'm still in week 1 and just need to get out the other side! Thanks if you've managed to read this!

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky  I had some peripheral neuropathy part way through which my oncologist monitored like a hawk and questioned me thoroughly at each review before we decided to continue each time. I loved the very simple test which would have been a deal breaker and mean it had to stop. He called it the stumbling and fumbling test. Basically if I experienced becoming clumsy and stumbling a lot, or clumsy and dropping things, unable to do buttons up etc. these were signs to stop - he also said if the tingling fuzziness in my fingers changed to actual numbness this was also a stop sign. Simple test here again was to press my nail into another finger tip - if I could feel it despite the fuzziness etc this was ok. I managed to do all of mine. My left hand is still fuzzy/tingly at times (last cycle 23 May) and was painfully achy at the end of the last one, ,y right hand is pretty much back to normal now. Strangely my feet had been ok but my toes became very painful after the last one. I am now taking gabapentin which is helping with the pain in my toes, and has stopped the ache in my hand. Hopefully over time it will all go away, but can cope if it doesn't. If you have any doubt or it is feeling numb or you are stumbling or fumbling  - stop, you've done enough!

Posts.Content: Hi Alison hp22 My initial emotional reaction on hearing I had BC was to have a mastectomy - at that time I thought it reduced the risk of it returning. As I learnt more, I realised it didn't. The only time a mastectomy reduce the risk is if you have it before getting primary cancer - ie the Angelina Jolie BRCA gene thing, which is what confuses people.  As I already had primary cancer, a mastectomy does not reduce the risk of secondary cancer. My oncologist told me that a lumpectomy plus radiotherapy is equal to a mastectomy in terms of risk reduction. My surgeon told me that there are studies that show that where breast conservation has been possible, this tends to link to a better quality of life - the reason being that mastectomy with or without reconstruction tends to impact more on how women feel about themselves. She also said that reconstructed breasts will never feel like a natural breast. Obviously if you don't have a choice this all goes by the wayside. I had chemo pre surgery which shrank my 5.5cm tumour to 3cm - and the circular tumour become flatter and more oval. This meant I could have a lumpectomy. As I needed quite a lot taken to achieve the clear margins, with some surface skin, and the nipple had to be removed (and my surgeon wasn't sure if she could save it) meaning I would have a smaller breast and be lopsided - I opted for therapeutic mammoplasty so that I had a cosmetic breast reduction (and lift!) with cancer removal. This looks amazing (and she managed to save the nipple and reattach) and as I was a 32H and had always wished for smaller this is a bonus. My surgeon wasn't prepared to do both breasts at the same time due to the harsh chemo regime I had been on for 6 months - two reasons, the length of the op would have been too much for me, and the risk of infection (high because of the chemo) would double. So I will be having my other breast reduced to match next April - she prefers 6 months post radiotherapy to allow my "done" breast to fully settle to ensure a good match!! I start radiotherapy in the next 2/3 weeks. I was also told that if clear margins were not achieved when the post op pathology results were available I would have to have a mastectomy  - so I guess there was a risk here that I might have had the first surgery for nothing - a risk I was happy to take. Thankfully margins and the three lymph nodes removed are all clear. Hope all this helps - I arrived at my decision after asking lots of questions so I fully understood the whole situation and felt able to make an informed decision that felt right for me.

Posts.Title: bit of a ramble starting to wobble!

Posts.Content: Hi Nic, nicnic I originally had a 6cm tumour and 8 cycles of chemo (Docetaxel and Cychlophosphamide) with a view to shrinking it. I had a good response - the tumour removed on 4 July was just over 3cm and spherical rather than round. Margins and the three lymph nodes removed were clear. Therapeutic mammoplasty (the techie name!) was muted when I first saw my breast care nurse as an option as I'm a 32H and had jokingly said that I'd always wanted smaller boobs! When I was told I didn't need a mastectomy and my surgeon would do breast conserving surgery it was discussed that I would be pretty lop sided due to the amount to be removed, and where it was, but they could sort for me at a later date if I wanted to. I asked about TM again and she said I was an ideal candidate - particularly as my breast tissue is exceptionally dense. After talking it through, I opted for this.  My surgeon said she would not do both at once - several reasons: - She said my chemo regime had been high dose and very taxing on my body and she didn't want to subject me to such a long op (the one I had was nearly four hours alone).  - In addition she said the risk of infection (high after my chemo) would be doubled due to double the amount of scars - the T junction point is a particularly iffy area for this, and my ability to fight lower. - the follow on radiotherapy can have an impact on the conserved/reduced breast and affect the shape and size, so better to let it all settle down so she can give me the best matching result - and do any adjustment needed to the one already done if necessary. - I could see if I was happy with the size and shape and she could adjust as necessary during the second op She was absolutely adamant that because of the first two reasons she would not do both at once as she "didn't work this way". All made perfect sense and I liked her reasoning, and her caution. So the op - went pretty much to plan. Slight complication as I bled excessively (not uncommon after chemo) so had a drain. This was out after about 5 days. I was excessively sick, which led to a couple of other problems, afterwards (chemo again) and had to stay in for 3 days rather than coming home the next day after the op - but I'm told this was more uncommon. The shape is amazing - slightly smaller (in her opinion) than she had anticipated due to tumour slightly bigger than the MRI had showed. We were aiming at a D/E (obviously they can't guarantee a particular size, it's not an exact thing!). No idea yet - but I think it looks amazing - very perky, no droop (breast lift thrown in!). She managed to save my nipple - which she hadn't thought she could due to where the tumour seemed to be attached - and made it smaller in keeping with my new breast. I've had a few problems with the wounds - so glad only had one done! Bit of infection after first week - soon sorted with antibiotics. Also after a couple of weeks the scarring - which looked so neat from day 1 like wallpaper butted up against each other, and the nipple didn't even look stitched on!) - I had an area underneath from right side that kind of unheaked itself (another chemo type weird thing as chemo can reverse the healing process!). So I've had about an inch and a half that has been very sore and needing me going to the clinic every week. Looks like it is improving now though at last. The actual after op pain is surprisingly much less than I was expecting - nothing like other ops I've had in the past. I was driving within 3 weeks. The scar from the lymph node removal was much the worse. So she was very right to say one at a time in my opinion - I have to say that my hospital seems pretty leading edge with all this stuff from surgeons, oncology and breast care nurses. I was given a comfy to balance me up - breast care nurse there the morning after to sort for me. I've just been fitted for an amazing silicon prosthesis which is very comfortable and I look completely normal - you wouldn't know I had two such different size breasts so this temporary period is fine. I'm waiting to start radiotherapy now - can't until wound fully healed. Seeing surgeon again in January with a view to surgery around April - she prefers 6 months post radiotherapy and I'm very happy to follow her advice - she has been superb, very caring and empathetic. So - hope that's not too much info and hope it helps a bit? Any questions, please ask. Main thing is I am really happy with the decision and looking forward to getting the other done - so go fir it!
